item.title: Canada and US Exchange Working Document on Trade Deal, CBC Says
item.description: US and Canadian officials are exchanging a document outlining potential trade deal terms, CBC News reported on Wednesday, citing anonymous sources, who said the paper is seen as a step toward a new trade pact.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Seal

media:content.media:description: Canadian and American flags near the Ambassador Bridge in Windsor, Ontario, Canada, on Friday, Jan. 24, 2025. President Donald Trump's tariffs against Canada and Mexico will threaten production at automakers across North America and send record vehicle prices even higher, with about a quarter of a trillion dollars in trade set to be disrupted.

item.title: Bessent Says ‘Remains to Be Seen’ Whether Tax Bill Adds to Debt
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent refrained from arguing that the tax legislation Republicans are working to finalize in Congress will avoid adding to the debt burden.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Ways and Means Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. A growing chorus of advisers inside and outside the Trump administration are pushing for Bessent to serve as the next chair of the Federal Reserve.

item.title: EU Likely to Be at ‘Very End’ of US Trade Deals, Lutnick Says
item.description: Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick said the European Union is likely to be among the last deals that the US completes, as the administration rushes to secure tariff agreements with other trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse

media:content.media:description: A operations at the Euromax Terminal in the Port of Rotterdam, in Rotterdam, Netherlands.

item.title: Polish Fiscal Risks Cast Shadow Over Tusk’s Renewed Mandate
item.description: Poland’s Prime Minister Donald Tusk failed to dispel doubts about his weakened government’s agenda despite winning a parliamentary vote of confidence in his cabinet.
item.dc:creator: Wojciech Moskwa, Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: The Palace of Science and Culture on the city skyline in Warsaw, Poland.

item.title: Paul Tudor Jones Sees Bessent as Trump Pick for Fed Chair
item.description: Paul Tudor Jones said President Donald Trump is likely to appoint an “uber dovish” Federal Reserve chair to accommodate his growth agenda, contending that Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent would likely be his pick when Jerome Powell’s term ends next year.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Cantrell, Katie Greifeld, Matthew Miller

media:content.media:description: Paul Tudor Jones

item.title: Trump Says China Will Ship Rare Earths in ‘Done’ Trade Deal
item.description: President Donald Trump said a trade framework with China has been completed, with Beijing supplying rare earths and magnets “UP FRONT” and the US allowing Chinese students into its colleges and universities.
item.dc:creator: Josh Wingrove, Skylar Woodhouse

item.title: South Africa Budget Approval in Sight After Tax Wrangle Ends
item.description: South Africa’s National Assembly approved the Treasury’s fiscal framework, bringing the adoption of the annual budget a step closer after months of wrangling over tax increases.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

media:content.media:description: Cape Town, South Africa.

item.title: US Core Inflation Rises Less Than Forecast for Fourth Month
item.description: Underlying US inflation rose in May by less than forecast for the fourth month in a row, suggesting companies are largely holding back on passing higher tariff costs through to consumers.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Atlanta, Georgia. Photographer: Dustin Chambers/Bloomberg

item.title: Reeves Vows Record Health Boost as She Turns On Spending Tap
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves announced a record funding boost for the National Health Service in a spending review that marks a watershed moment for the Labour government after nearly a year in power focused on fiscal prudence.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Alex Wickham, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Rachel Reeves ahead of presenting the spending review, on June 11. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Credits Trump Policies for ‘Substantial’ CPI Improvement
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent credited President Donald Trump’s policies for a slowdown in US inflation, and said he had challenged a “decades-old status quo” on trade.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran

media:content.media:description: US President Donald Trump and Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary.

item.title: Here Are the Key Takeaways From the US CPI Report for May
item.description: Here are the key takeaways from today’s May US consumer price index report, released Wednesday:
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Shoppers carry bags in the Soho neighborhood of New York. Photographer: Adam Gray/Bloomberg

item.title: China Found World’s Pain Point on Trade — and Will Use It Again
item.description: For months Donald Trump pushed tariffs and trade restrictions on China to unprecedented levels, part of a strategy to force Xi Jinping into talks the US president expected would help cut the trade deficit and boost American manufacturing.
item.dc:creator: Martin Ritchie, Alberto Nardelli, Laura Curtis

media:content.media:description: NdFeB alloy strip at the Australia Strategic Materials Ltd.'s Korean Metals Plant, in the Ochang Foreign Investment Zone, in Cheongju, South Korea, on Tuesday, June 10, 2025.

item.title: Bessent Says ‘We Will See’ If China Is Reliable on Trade

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, arrives for a House Ways and Means Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 11, 2025. Bessent credited President Donald Trump’s policies for a slowdown in US inflation, and said he had challenged a “decades-old status quo” on trade.

item.title: UK’s Reeves Commits £39 Billion to Build More Affordable Housing
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves committed £39 billion ($52.6 billion) to affordable housebuilding in the UK spending review, as the government seeks to regain momentum in its bid to build 1.5 million homes.
item.dc:creator: Damian Shepherd

media:content.media:description: Newly built homes in Bishops Stortford, UK. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Dollar-Obsessed Argentines Have a Newfound Love for Buying Gold
item.description: Gold is winning over the hearts of Argentines, a nation once almost irrationally devoted to the dollar.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: A box with gold bars at Banco Piano in Buenos Aires. The bank is one of a few institutions that sell physical gold with a certificate of origin and a top purity rating.

item.title: Cocoa, Gold Rebound Drives Ghana’s Economic Growth Surge
item.description: Ghana’s economy expanded at the fastest pace since the third quarter of last year after its gold and cocoa industries exited contractions.
item.dc:creator: Ekow Dontoh, Moses Mozart Dzawu

media:content.media:description: Ghana is the world’s second-biggest cocoa supplier.

item.title: Cool US CPI Boosts Bets on Two Fed Rate Cuts by Year-End

media:content.media:description: A customer looks at clothing for sale at the Pike Place Market in Seattle. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Noisy Trade Wars Shift Into Duller Framework Implementation Stage
item.description: President Donald Trump returned to the White House in January pledging to overhaul the US’s trade relationships using his brash style of frenzied deal-making.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

item.title: ECB to Speed Up Reviews of Share Buyback Plans by European Banks
item.description: European banks’ wait time for regulatory approvals for their shareholder payout plans is about to get shorter, as the region’s top watchdog steps up efforts to boost efficiency.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort

media:content.media:description: The ECB headquarters, right, in Frankfurt. Photographer: Andreas Rentz/Getty Images

item.title: ‘Travel in China’ Push Sees Foreign Spending Begin to Affect GDP
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at the emergence of foreign travel as an increasingly relevant sector for China’s economy. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

media:content.media:description: Visitors at the Badaling section of the Great Wall in Beijing, China, on Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024. China expects domestic trips and tourist spending in the first nine months of 2024 to rise 16.8% and 17.1% on-year, respectively, inching closer to full-year 2019 level, according to an official briefing on Monday. Photographer: Andrea Verdelli/Bloomberg

item.title: Italy Can Achieve or Even Beat GDP Goal for 2025, Giorgetti Says
item.description: Italy faces a tricky global backdrop but is still well positioned to achieve its economic growth target for this year if not even to beat it, according to the country’s finance minister.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in Milan.

item.title: The Euro Struggles to Win Over Czechs Going Slow on Adoption
item.description: The Czech central bank governor touted the benefits of his country’s currency, saying that the koruna puts it in a better position to moderate price-growth than the euro would.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Krystof Chamonikolas, Kriti Gupta

media:content.media:description: Ales Michl in Prague, on June 10. Photographer: Milan Jaros/Bloomberg

item.title: US, China Officials Agree on Plan That Awaits Xi, Trump Sign-Off
item.description: The US and China capped two days of high-stakes trade talks with a plan to revive the flow of sensitive goods — a framework now awaiting the blessing of Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Annmarie Hordern

item.title: Romania’s Top Bank CEO Expects Post-Election Economic Boost
item.description: Romania’s economy is poised for a boost from the election of a pro-European president, outweighing risks from fiscal imbalances and US President Donald Trump’s tariff war, according to the head of the country’s biggest bank.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

item.title: US Tariff Limbo Gives Canadian Warehouses a New Lease on Life
item.description: With US bonded facilities increasingly full, importers find that stockpiling goods north of the border works just as well.
item.dc:creator: Ari Altstedter

media:content.media:description: Workers at Windsor Fulfillment Corp. unload a truck earlier this month.

item.title: ECB’s Lane Says June Cut Helps Keep Price Undershoot Temporary
item.description: The European Central Bank’s latest reduction in borrowing costs will guard against inflation getting stuck below 2%, according to Chief Economist Philip Lane.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: Traders Boost Bets on Just One 2025 Fed Cut Ahead of CPI
item.description: Traders are increasingly betting that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates only once this year amid signs of resilient growth and sticky inflation.
item.dc:creator: Edward Bolingbroke

item.title: Mexico’s Pledge to Give Deportees Jobs Hits Snag Over US Flights
item.description: Mexico’s government has pledged to provide jobs for citizens deported from the US, but recent data shows that barely 4% of the tens of thousands expelled since late January have been matched with employment.
item.dc:creator: Amy Stillman, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: Migrants at the Mexican refugee commission, following the suspension of CBP One appointments, in Tapachula, Mexico, on Jan. 27.

item.title: Bank of England Urges Lenders to Step Up Repo Facilities Use
item.description: The Bank of England has urged lenders to step up use of its routine liquidity facilities to avoid possible stresses in markets as the central bank runs down its balance sheet.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: The Bank of England in the City of London. Photographer: Jose Sarmento Matos/Bloomberg

item.title: Euro’s Steady Demand Shows Challenge of Taking On the Dollar
item.description: International use of the euro remained flat for another year in 2024, laying bare the depth of the task in challenging the US dollar on the global stage.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers
